H0.text: Water would be used less by farmers who plant Bt cotton, because the insect‑toxic genes in the cotton reduce the need for pesticide spraying and therefore the amount of water normally applied for such treatments.

H1.text: Fertilizer is the product that farmers using Bt cotton would most likely use less of because the insect‑killing genes inserted into the cotton reduce pest damage and thereby lower the overall input requirements for crop production.

H2.text: Herbicide is the chemical that farmers who use Bt cotton would most likely use less of, because the cotton contains insecticidal genes from the soil bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis.

H3.text: Insecticide is the product that farmers using Bt cotton would most likely use less of, because the cotton contains genes from the insecticidal bacterium Bacillus thuringiensis.

A4.text: Reduction in insecticide use in the cultivation of Bt cotton in which bollworms are major pests.

A5.text: After seven years these secondary pests that were normally controlled by pesticide had increased, necessitating the use of pesticides at similar levels to non-Bt cotton.

A6.text: The increase in insecticide use for the control of these secondary insects was far smaller than the reduction in total insecticide use due to Bt cotton adoption.

A7.text: Another study in five provinces in China found the reduction in pesticide use in Bt cotton cultivars is significantly lower than that reported in research elsewhere.

A8.text: The first transgenic crop, which incorporated an insecticidal PIP, contained a gene for the CRY toxin from Bacillus thuringiensis (B.t.) and was introduced in 1997.

A9.text: The toxins from B.t. have been incorporated into plants through genetic engineering.
